topics.title: Internal triggers, not tech, cause distraction
topics.summary: Nir explains that even removing technology didn’t stop his distractions, because the real driver is discomfort and internal triggers. He frames distraction as escaping feelings, which is empowering because it can be managed with tools.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Nir Eyal, his books (Hooked, Indistractable), and sets the goal of sharing tactical methods to improve focus and reduce distraction.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Vanta and Jira Product Discovery.

topics.title: Why Nir wrote Indistractable; common myths
topics.summary: Nir shares he wrote the book because he struggled with distraction for years and found conventional advice (quit tech) impractical. He argues most people know what to do, but don’t know how to stop self-sabotaging via distraction.

topics.title: Defining distraction: traction vs distraction
topics.summary: Nir defines traction and distraction as actions pulled by intent, emphasizing that even “work tasks” (like email) can be distractions if they’re not what you intended to do. This reframes distraction as something we do, not something done to us.

topics.title: Four-step framework to become indistractable
topics.summary: Nir outlines the four steps: master internal triggers, make time for traction, hack back external triggers, and prevent distraction with pacts. Lenny asks for a recap and Nir clarifies what each step covers beyond just notifications.

topics.title: Diagnosing Lenny’s distraction: avoiding hard thinking
topics.summary: They apply the framework to Lenny’s habit of checking Twitter/email instead of writing, identifying the internal trigger as discomfort from “cold start” deep work. Nir emphasizes the root cause is emotional discomfort, not devices.

topics.title: The 10-minute rule and surfing the urge
topics.summary: Nir teaches a practical technique: delay distraction by 10 minutes, observe the urge like a wave, and use a mantra (“this is what it feels like to get better”). He argues this builds agency by proving you can postpone impulses.

topics.title: Timeboxing values: calendar over to-do lists
topics.summary: Nir explains you can’t label something a distraction unless you know what it distracted you from, so you must timebox traction on your calendar (including leisure and relationships). He describes weekly planning around values across self, relationships, and work (reactive vs reflective).

topics.title: Pacts and stakes: precommitment and price contracts
topics.summary: Nir introduces “pacts” as a last-resort firewall, including price pacts where failing to act costs money, illustrating how higher stakes reveal you can make time. Lenny shares his own deep-work calendar blocks as a practical parallel.

topics.title: Why to-do lists fail; measure time, not tasks
topics.summary: Nir argues to-do lists lack constraints and feedback loops, fueling guilt and poor estimation (planning fallacy). He recommends measuring success by doing what you planned for the planned duration without distraction, which improves estimation and output quality.

topics.title: Deadlines, procrastination, and emotion regulation
topics.summary: They discuss deadline-driven work and why it often harms quality. Nir frames procrastination as an emotion regulation problem (not a character flaw) and says the solution starts with managing internal triggers plus scheduling distraction-free work time.

topics.title: Motivation: escaping discomfort drives behavior
topics.summary: Nir challenges the ‘pleasure principle,’ arguing all motivation is about escaping discomfort—‘the carrot is the stick.’ Lenny asks for more internal-trigger tools; Nir previews additional techniques and reiterates internal triggers must be addressed first.
